org.jdesktop.swingx.table
Class AbstractColumn<_RowType,_ValueType>

java.lang.Object
  org.jdesktop.swingx.table.AbstractColumn<_RowType,_ValueType>
Type Parameters:
_RowType - The type of each row of the JTable
_ValueType - The type of value for the cells in this JTable.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.beans.PropertyChangeListener, java.util.EventListener
Direct Known Subclasses:
PropertyColumn
public abstract class AbstractColumn<_RowType,_ValueType>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.beans.PropertyChangeListener

Abstract Column
_RowType is the class for each row in the table.

This class makes no assumptions about the form of the data in _RowType Typically, this class is subclassed to implement a getValue() method, and potentially a setValue() method, but the rest of the properties are set in the constructor. This makes subclasses very easy to write. For example, a column to display the price property of an instance of class Product would look like this: 

  private static class PriceColumn extends AbstractColumn<Product, Double> {
      PriceColumn() {
          super("Price",             // Column Name
                Double.class,        // Column class
                65,                  // Column Width
                mMoneyRenderer       // TableCellRenderer
          );
      }
      public Double     getValue(Product row) { return row.getPrice(); }
      public void       setValue(Double pr, Product row) { row.setPrice(pr); }
      public boolean    isEditable(Product pNum) { return true; }
  }
The constructors here can't possibly give us every needed combination of parameters, but developers can easily write a subclass with any other constructors they need. In the example above, a constructor that includes a value for the editable property would be useful, particularly if several columns needed it.

Caution: When subclassing, be sure to say extends AbstractColumn{@literal <R, V>} instead of extends AbstractColumn, or you will get confusing error messages with any method you override.

Author:
Miguel Muñoz

getComparableValue

public java.lang.Comparable<?> getComparableValue(_RowType pRow)
This is used for sorting, when the KeyedTableRowSorter is used. By default this method doesn't use keyed sorting. Instead, it follows the following rules:
1) If the _ValueType is a String, it returns an instance of StringComparable for the String returned by the getValue() method.
2) Otherwise, if the _ValueType implements Comparable, it calles getValue() and returns that if result.
3) If the _ValueType does not implement Comparable, it calls convertToString() to convert the object to a String, then returns an instance of StringComparable for that String.

To use keyed sorting, which is the purpose of this method, you should override this to return a sorting key derived from the value returned by getValue(). Typically, you would return a CollationKey created from a String, using Collator. Although the default behavior of the standard TableRowSorter uses these same CollationKeys, you can speed up the sorting by generating the keys ahead of time, and returning them from this method. For example: 

 public class RowData {
   String name;
   CollationKey nameKey;
   ...
   public void setName(String name) {
     this.name = name;
     nameKey = Collator.getInstance().getCollationKey(name);
   }
   ...
 }
 

 public class NameColumn extends AbstractColumn<RowData, String> {
   ...
   public Comparable<?> getComparableValue(RowData theRow) {
     return theRow.nameKey;
   }
 }

Parameters:
pRow - The row
Returns:
The comparable object to be used in sorting the rows.
See Also:
Collator, CollationKey, TableRowKeyedSorter, convertToString(Object), AbstractColumn.StringComparable

isEditable

public boolean isEditable(_RowType pRow)
Columns are not editable by default. You may make the columns editable by setting the isEditable property to true, or by overriding this method.

Parameters:
pRow - The row
Returns:
true if the row is editable, false otherwise.

getUpdateRow

public boolean getUpdateRow(_RowType pRow)
Specifies if changes to the current cell will cause changes elsewhere in the same row. By default this returns false. If changes to this cell can force changes to other cells in the same row then this method should be overridden to return true.

Parameters:
pRow - The row that is changing.
Returns:
true if changes to this cell force changes to other cells in the same row, false otherwise.
See Also:
SeparatedTableModel.setValueAt(Object,int,int)

getUpdateTable

public boolean getUpdateTable(_RowType pRow)
Specifies if changes to the current cell will cause changes elsewhere in the table, in other rows. By default this returns false. If changes to this cell can force changes to cells in other rows then this method should be overridden return true.

Parameters:
pRow - The row that is changing.
Returns:
true if changes to this cell force changes to other rows in the table, false otherwise.
See Also:
SeparatedTableModel.setValueAt(Object,int,int)

getUpdateSubsequentRows

public boolean getUpdateSubsequentRows(_RowType pRow)
Specifies if changes to the current cell will cause changes elsewhere in the table, in subsequent rows, but not in preceeding rows. By default this returns false. If changes to this cell can force changes to cells in other rows below this one then this method should be overridden to return true.

Parameters:
pRow - The row that is changing.
Returns:
true if changes to this cell force changes to rows below this cell, false otherwise.

propertyChange

public void propertyChange(java.beans.PropertyChangeEvent evt)
This method gets called when a bound property is changed.

Note: This is only useful when the model is used by only one JTable. If more than one JTable use this model, this would prevent the user from setting a different column width in each table. Note2: This method probably doesn't work anyway, because the user probably doesn't change the preferred width when adjusting column separators. todo: Figure out if this works.

Specified by:
propertyChange in interface java.beans.PropertyChangeListener
Parameters:
evt - A PropertyChangeEvent object describing the event source and the property that has changed.

convertToString

public java.lang.String convertToString(_ValueType value)
When using the TableRowKeyedSorter, converts the value to a String for sorting purposes. The default behavior just calls toString(), but you may override this for custom behavior. This method replaces the functionality of the TableStringConverter.

Parameters:
value - The value of the table cell.
Returns:
The value converted to a String.
See Also:
TableRowKeyedSorter
